doc.repnme: La désertification dans les zones sahélienne et soudanienne de l'Afrique de l'Ouest
doc.abstracts: This paper stresses that desertification is a process of continuous decline in biological productivity of arid and semi-arid areas that are being transformed gradually into desert or skeletal soils. This phenomenon is observed now in many parts of the Sahelian and Sudanian areas of West Africa. The question of whether desertification is mainly due to droughts and increasing aridity or by misuse of resources by the local population is highly debated. However, this debate does not lead to practical conclusions in that whereas rainfall cannot still be changed or even expected it is still possible to influence human behavior. The behavior of people in Sahelian West Africa is conditioned by two fundamental ecological characteristics: rainfall is variable and less predictable and abundant from south to north of the region; the soil is poor, being very fertile and very poor in phosphorus and nitrogen. The authors conclude that it should be noted that in the central strip of Sahelian West Africa, no significant change in the carrying capacity is possible without major technological innovations. Locally, however, it is possible to avoid the danger of desertification through appropriate control and working with communities that aspire to prevent desertification and are empowered to use their land in a sustainable productive manner. It is essential to reduce the rapid and continuous encroachment of the population and alleviate the current demographic pressures which act on the central band in further encouraging the existing phenomenon of spontaneous movements to the Sudan-Guinean under-populated area, with considerable potential.
